Developing simple and efficient catalytic systems for cleaving bridged linkages in lignin has emerged as a promising valorization strategy. In this work, a series of Ni/CeO2 catalysts calcined at 400-800 °C were prepared and evaluated for the selective hydrogenolysis of lignin-derived aryl ethers. Among them, Ni/CeO2-500 demonstrated optimal activity, achieving complete conversion of benzyl phenyl ether (BPE) at 100 °C with 100% selectivity to toluene and phenol (no detectable arene hydrogenation byproducts). For the more robust β-O-4 and 4-O-5 model compounds, 71%-100% conversion with 81.22%-100% selectivity to aromatic monomers were attained at 180°C. Catalyst characterization revealed that calcination at 500 °C optimized oxygen vacancy (Ov) concentration as evidenced by XPS analysis of OIII/OI+OII ratio and Ce³⁺/Ce⁴⁺ ratio. Furthermore, density functional theory (DFT) calculations elucidated a dual-site mechanism: Ni sites facilitate H₂ dissociation and interaction with aromatic rings, and adjacent Ov sites activate C-O bonds via coordination to oxygen-containing functional groups. The synergistic Ni-Ov cooperation enhances substrate adsorption and lowers the C-O bond dissociation energy by 1.04-1.32 eV, thereby promoting selective hydrogenolysis over arene hydrogenation at lower temperatures. The Ni/CeO₂-500 system demonstrates significant potential for efficient lignin depolymerization under mild conditions, offering new insights for designing non-noble metal catalysts in biomass valorization. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Selective hydrogenolysis Arene hydrogenation Ni/CeO2 α-O-4 bonds β-O-4 bonds Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the increasing risk of depletion and environmental problems caused by the overuse of traditional fossil fuels, it is imperative to promote the diversification of energy development [1,2]. Biomass, with advantages including abundant reserves, natural renewability and low environmental footprint, owns the potential to replace traditional fossil feedstocks in producing bulk chemicals and fuels in the future [3]. As one of the three major components of lignocellulose biomass [4], lignin accounts for about 15-30 wt% but remains underutilized due to the robust and complex macromolecular architecture [5]. The natural three-dimensional organic polymer consists of phenylpropane structural units [6–8] interconnected by C-C and C-O bridge bonds, where C-O bonds comprise approximately two thirds of total inter-unit connections, mainly including α-O-4, β-O-4 and 4-O-5 linkages. Selective breakage of these ubiquitous C-O bonds is crucial for lignin depolymerization. Current strategies include pyrolysis [9], hydrogenolysis [10] and oxidation [11], and among them catalytic hydrogenolysis is considered the most promising method for high conversion and aromatic monomer selectivity [12,13]. Hydrogenolysis is typically performed over noble metals (eg., Ru [14], Rh [15], Pd [16,17] and Pt [18]) or non-noble metals (eg., Ni [19,20], Fe [21], Cu [22] and Co, etc. [23]). Although noble metal-based catalysts exhibit high catalytic activity for lignin and model compounds, they often cause aromatic ring over-hydrogenation and thus compromise lignin’s potential as feedstocks for functionalized aromatics. Additionally, high cost and sulfur sensitivity limit their industrial application. Consequently, non-noble nickel-based catalysts have garnered considerable interests due to low cost and tunability [24,25]. However, the lower intrinsic activity of Ni catalysts makes the development of efficient Ni-based catalysts for low-temperature and low-pressure application highly challenging yet promising. Bimetallic modification represents a key strategy to boost the performance of Ni-based catalysts. Marin et al. [26] reported that hydrogenolysis of benzyl phenyl ether (BPE) over Fe-Ni catalysts at 170 °C, yielding sustained 50% selectivity for both toluene and cyclohexanol. Zhu et al. [27] achieved near-complete BPE cleavage (96.8% toluene and 90.3% phenol) over Ni-Ru bimetallic catalyst under milder conditions (120 °C and 0.5 MPa H2), which effectively suppressed phenol hydrogenation to cyclohexanol, implying a synergistic Ni-Ru interactions. Metal oxides supported Ni-based catalysts represent another prevalent strategy for modulating the electronic structure and enhancing catalytic performance through Ni-support interactions. Besides excellent structural stability, these oxides improve Ni dispersion and provide Brönsted acid and/or Lewis acid sites, which polarize C-O bonds thus facilitating cleavage and enabling an energy-efficient hydrogenolysis process. Therefore, a variety of metal oxides or their combinations, including Al2O3[28], SiO2[29], Nb2O5[30], SiO2-Al2O3[31], ZnO-Al2O3[32], ZrO2-MoO3[33], CeO2[34–36], etc. have been used as supports for Ni-based catalysts in the depolymerization of lignin or lignin models. Among them, CeO2, with abundant oxygen vacancies arising from the redox cycle of Ce4+/Ce3+, exhibits a strong oxophilicity which enhances adsorption and activation of oxygen-containing lignin models and lignin [37], and hence promotes the rupture of C-O linkages. Given the critical role of oxygen vacancies in governing the performance of CeO₂-supported catalysts, we used calcination, a simple but facile method for Ov generation, to systematically investigated the effects of calcination temperature (400-800°C) on Oᵥ concentration in Ni/CeO₂ catalysts. Comprehensive characterization of XRD, XPS, SEM, TEM, and Raman spectroscopy revealed Ni/CeO₂-500 possesses maximal Oᵥ density. Catalytic evaluation using lignin model compounds (benzyl phenyl ether, BPE; 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol, 2-PPE) demonstrated that Ni/CeO₂-500 catalyst exhibited optimal performance, outperforming both Ni/CeO₂-T counterparts calcinated at other temperatures and commercial Ru/C and Pd/C catalysts. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations mechanistically confirmed that Ni and neighboring Oᵥ sites synergistically lower the C-O bond dissociation energy barrier by 1.04-1.32 ev [34], thereby preferentially facilitating C-O cleavage over arene hydrogenation. 2 Experimental Section 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ni/CeO2 catalysts were prepared via incipient wetness impregnation followed by calcination at controlled temperatures. First, CeO₂ support was prepared by thermal decomposition of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O in a muffle furnace, heating from ambient temperature to 800 °C at 3 °C•min-1 under static air with a 4 h isothermal hold. Then, 0.8 g activated CeO2 was impregnated with an aqueous solution containing 0.6 g Ni(NO₃)₂·6H₂O and 0.14 g polyethylene glycol in 50 mL of deionized water. The mixture was magnetically stirred (600 rpm, 12 h), rotary-evaporated at 75 °C, and then vacuum-dried (120 °C, 24 h). The dried precursor was ground and calcined in air (3 °C min⁻¹) to target temperature (400∼800 °C, 4 h). Final activation involved temperature-programmed reduction in H2: ramped at 3 °C·min⁻¹ to 500 °C with 4 h hold, yielding Ni/CeO2-T catalysts (T = calcination temperature). 2.2 Catalytic reaction Reactions were performed in a 50-mL stainless steel autoclave (Yanzheng Shanghai Experimental Instrument Co., Ltd). Typically, 50 mg model compounds, 5-45 mg catalyst and 15 mL isopropanol were loaded. The reactor was purged with H2 five times to evacuate air, then pressurized to 0.5-2.5 MPa hydrogen pressure. After sealing, the reactor was heated to target temperature at 500 rpm stirring and held isothermally for 0.5-2.5 h. Reactions were quenched by rapid cooling with an electric fan. Upon reaching room temperature, residual H₂ was slowly vented through a pressure-release valve, and the catalyst was removed by a magnetic rod. Then, the liquid phase was mixed with 30 μL n-dodecane (internal standard) and diluted to 15 mL with isopropanol. Product analysis employed GC-MS (Agilent 7890B/5977A) with 1 μL splitless injection. The conversion and selectivity were calculated as: (1) Conversion = ( moles of substrate reacted / moles of substrate supplied ) × 100 % (2) Selectivity = ( moles of producti / ∑ moles of products ) × 100 % 2.3 Density functional theory (DFT) calculation All the quantum chemical calculations for BPE and 2-PPE reactions over Ni/CeO2-500 were performed using the Vienna Ab inito Simulation Package (VASP) [38]. Take 15 Å as the vacuum layer in the z-direction to minimize periodic interactions. Structural optimizations converged at energy and force thresholds of 1.0×10-4 eV and 0.02 eV•Å-1, respectively. The Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) for each elementary step was defined as (3) Δ G = Δ E + Δ ZPE − T Δ S Where ΔE represents electronic energy difference, T means temperature and ΔS means entropy change, and ΔZPE denotes zero-point energy difference. Zero-point energy (ZPE) was calculated as [39] (4) ZPE = 1 2 ∑ h v i The TS (transition state) energy of adsorbed species was given according to the vibrational frequencies [40]: (5) TS = k B T [ ∑ k ln ( 1 1 − e − hv / k B T ) + ∑ k hv k B T 1 ( e hv / k B T − 1 ) + 1 ] 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1a shows XRD patterns of CeO2 and Ni/CeO2-T catalysts. Both the support and Ni/CeO2-T samples exhibit nine distinct diffraction peaks characteristic of fluorite-structured CeO2 (PDF No. 34-0394) [41], confirming the retention of the cubic phase even after Ni loading. Additional peaks at 44.5° and 51.7°, correspond to the (111) and (200) planes of face-centered cubic Ni0 (PDF No. 04-0850), indicating successful reduction of Ni2+ to Ni0 after hydrogen treatment. Moreover, as the calcination temperature increases, the diffraction peaks of both Ni0 and CeO2 become sharper and more intense, suggesting that high calcination temperatures induce the phase transition from amorphous phase to well-defined crystalline phases. An optimal crystalline-amorphous phase balance is crucial for catalytic performance, as abundant oxygen vacancy defects (OVDs) predominantly form at amorphous regions or crystalline-amorphous interfaces. Given the correlation between oxygen vacancy density and catalytic activity, calcination temperature significantly influences Ni/CeO₂-T catalytic behavior. Fig. 1b reveals that for Ni/CeO2-500 catalysts with varying Ni loadings, the diffraction intensity of Ni0 species increases as the Ni loading rises from 5 to 15 wt%, while a further increase to 20 wt% attenuates the signal. Obviously, an excessively high Ni loading inhibits crystalline phase formation due to particle aggregation, hence 15 wt% is identified as the optimal loading. As summarized in Table 1 , the interplanar spacing of CeO2 increases slightly after H2 reduction due to partial reduction of Ce4+ to the larger Ce3+. Based on the Scherrer formula and Ni (111) diffraction peak parameters, the average diameters of Ni nanoparticles in Ni/CeO2-400, Ni/CeO2-500 and Ni/CeO2-600 were calculated to be 40.26 nm, 50.26 nm and 51.48 nm, respectively. This progressive increase confirms that higher calcination temperatures promote the growth of Ni nanoparticles. Furthermore, the sharper and more intense metallic Ni0 diffraction peaks indicate enhanced crystallinity and higher concentration of Ni0 species, which could lead to a higher density of accessible active sites and improved catalytic performance. SEM and TEM images provided insights into the morphology of Ni/CeO2-T. Fig. 2a and 2b show the morphological evolution of Ni/CeO2-500 from irregular, uneven surfaces to smooth, uniform block-shaped particles after H2 reduction (500 °C). This transition suggests that significant densification and partial aggregation occur during reduction. TEM imaging (Fig. 2c) reveals homogeneous dispersion of Ni nanoparticles on CeO2 with an average size of 12.15 nm, significantly smaller than the crystallite sizes estimated by XRD (Table 1). This discrepancy stems from the intrinsic limitations of XRD to underestimate the small, low-crystallinity particles while over-representing larger, high-ordered crystallites that dominate the diffraction signal, thereby resulting in a size overestimation [42]. HRTEM imaging (Fig. 2d) further confirms lattice fringes with spacings of 0.3106 nm and 0.2040 nm, corresponding to CeO2 (111) and Ni (111) planes, respectively. The close interfacial contact between Ni and CeO2 indicates a potential synergistic effect that may enhance catalytic performance. XPS analysis was conducted to investigate the surface chemical composition and oxidation states of Ni/CeO2-500. The survey spectrum (Fig. 3a ) identifies the presence of Ni, Ce and O, consistent with the expected catalyst composition. Deconvolution of the Ni 2p region (Fig. 3b) reveals four characteristic peaks: a satellite at around 861.0 eV, a peak at 855.7 eV related to Ni2+ in Ni(OH)2, a peak at 854.1 eV assigned to Ni2+ in NiO, and a peak at 852.2 eV indicative of Ni0 species. The observed surface Ni²⁺ species primarily originate from surface oxidation of metallic Ni⁰ upon air exposure during storage. Based on the integrated areas of the deconvoluted peaks, the relative concentrations of Ni²⁺and Ni⁰ were determined to be 88% and 12%, respectively. Despite the high proportion of Ni²⁺, the majority of these species can be reduced to active Ni⁰ under reaction conditions (H2 atmosphere), resulting in catalytic activity comparable to that of the fresh catalyst, as supported by control experiments of the long-term stored and fresh Ni/CeO2-500. The Ce 3d spectrum of Ni/CeO2-500 catalysts (Fig. 3c) can be deconvoluted into ten subpeaks. Peaks at 881.4 eV, 885.1 eV, 900.5 eV and 903.4 eV are assigned to Ce3+ species, while those at 882.2 eV, 887.4 eV, 898.1 eV, 901.2 eV, 907.1 eV and 916.4 eV correspond to Ce4+ species. The confirmed co-existence of Ce3+/Ce4+ redox pairs on the surface of the catalyst [43] facilitates oxygen vacancy formation, leading to superior catalytic performance. The O 1s XPS spectrum (Fig. 3d) reveals three distinct oxygen species: lattice oxygen (O²⁻) coordinated to Ce⁴⁺ at 529.4 eV, lattice oxygen bound to Ce³⁺ at 528.8 eV, and surface adsorbed -OH or -CO groups onto oxygen vacancies at 531.4 eV. The coexistence of Ce³⁺ and Ce⁴⁺-related lattice oxygen demonstrates the mixed valence states of Ce in Ni/CeO₂-500. When Ni is incorporated into CeO2 lattice, Ce4+ is reduced to Ce3+ which disrupts the long-term periodicity of lattice oxygen and generates oxygen vacancies for charge balance. Additionally, hydrogen reduction simultaneously generates Ce3+ species and oxygen vacancies. To further understand the effect of calcination temperature on oxygen vacancy concentration, we performed XPS analysis on catalyst precursors calcinated at different temperatures. As defined in Fig. 4a , OI and OII peaks are attributed to lattice oxygen connected to Ce3+ and Ce4+, respectively, while OIII peaks represent chemisorbed oxygen species (-OH/-COₓ) on oxygen vacancies. Then we employed two established quantitative analysis to evaluate the Ov concentration of Ni/CeO2-T [44]: the OIII/(OI+OII) ratio as a direct indicator, and the OI/(OI+OII) ratio, which is proportional to Ce³⁺ concentration and thus serve as an indirect index for Ov concentration. As summarized in Table 2 , NiO/CeO2-500 exhibits the highest OIII/(OI+OII) ratio (1.99), indicating its maximal Ov density. This is corroborated by its concurrently elevated OI/(OI+OII) ratio (0.29). These complementary metrics provide mutually consistent characterization of oxygen vacancy concentration, jointly demonstrating 500°C as the optimal calcination temperature for oxygen vacancy generation. Since the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ species contributes to oxygen vacancy formation, we quantified Ce³⁺/Ce⁴⁺ratios by integrating the areas of the four Ce3+ peaks and six Ce4+ peaks and calculating their relative proportions in the Ce 3d XPS spectra (Fig. 4b). Significantly, NiO/CeO2-500 still exhibits the highest Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio (0.42, Table 2), in line with O 1s analysis, reconfirming 500 °C as the optimal calcination temperature for oxygen vacancy maximization. Raman spectroscopy was employed to probe the structural evolution of CeO2, NiO/CeO2-500 and Ni/CeO2-500, as depicted in Fig. 5a . The dominant peak at 466 cm-1 is related to the F2g mode of fluorite-structured CeO2. Weak bands at 600 cm-1 and 1200 cm-1 represent the defect- associated (D) mode and second-order longitudinal optical (2LO) mode, respectively [45]. Compared to pristine CeO2, both NiO/CeO2-500 and Ni/CeO2-500 exhibit downshifted, broadened, and intensity-reduced F2g bands, suggesting the symmetric Ce-O-Ce vibration distortion caused by oxygen vacancies defects. Concurrently, enhanced D-band and 2LO-band intensities confirm elevated oxygen vacancy concentration induced by calcination and Ni incorporation. NH3-TPD profiles of 15% Ni/CeO2-T series (Fig. 5b) reveal distinct acid site distributions. Ni/CeO2-500 exhibits three desorption peaks: a weak, broad peak at 134.5 °C attributed to weak acid sites, a pronounced medium-strength acid peak at 397.3 °C, and a unique high-temperature peak at 687.1 °C absent in other samples. Quantitative analysis (Table S2) confirms Ni/CeO2-500 possesses the highest concentration of medium-strength acid sites (0.035 mmol/g). This enhanced acidity originates from abundant oxygen vacancies generated under optimized calcination conditions. The 687.1°C desorption peak is correlated with proton-donating hydroxyls adsorbed onto oxygen vacancy sites, a configuration supposed to facilitate C-O bond activation in lignin model compounds. 3.2 Catalytic hydrogenolysis of BPE To evaluate the effect of calcination temperature on catalyst performance, the hydrogenolysis of benzyl phenyl ether (BPE) was conducted over Ni/CeO2-T catalysts under mild conditions (100 °C, 1.5 MPa H2, 2 h). As listed in Table 3 , Ni/CeO2-500 achieved complete BPE conversion (100%) with exclusive formation of toluene and phenol in a 1:1 molar ratio. No arene hydrogenation byproducts (e.g., methylcyclohexane, cyclohexanol, cyclohexanone) were detected. Other Ni/CeO₂-T catalysts exhibited lower BPE conversions (30.5%–85.0%), yet maintained exclusive selectivity to toluene and phenol in a 1:1 ratio. In contrast, commercial Ru/C and Pd/C catalysts achieved 77.3%-100% BPE conversion (entries 7-8) but produced complexed products mixtures including toluene, methylcyclohexane, cyclohexanol and either benzene and cyclohexylmethanol or cyclohexanone. Thus, the synthesized Ni/CeO2-T catalysts selectively cleave C-O bond in BPE instead of hydrogenating arenes, demonstrating superior selectivity over commercial catalysts. Given the nearly identical Ni loadings across all synthesized Ni/CeO2-T catalysts (11.25∼12.48 wt%, Table S1), the observed performance differences are primarily attributed to calcination-induced variations in oxygen vacancy concentrations, as quantitatively confirmed by XPS. Hydrogenolysis proceeds exclusively on the catalyst surface via an adsorbed-phase mechanism. As electron-deficient centers, these oxygen vacancies facilitate BPE adsorption via coordination to its oxygen-containing groups, generate Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites that polarize, elongate and distort C-O bonds, ultimately enabling selective C-O cleavage via hydrogen transfer from activated H2. Additionally, oxygen vacancies serve as nucleation sites for Ni particles, anchoring them onto the support surface. This inhibits Ni sintering while enhancing Ni dispersion, as evidenced by SEM-EDS analysis (Fig. S1). Moreover, the ferromagnetic properties of Ni/CeO2-500 enabled facile magnetic separation from the reaction mixture for catalyst recycling. BPE conversion remained at 100% over four consecutive reaction cycles, and decreased only slightly to 92.7% in the fifth run owing to the formation of minimal, graphitic coke (Fig. S2-S4), demonstrating excellent catalyst stability. Therefore, given the high BPE conversion and exceptional selectivity toward aromatic monomers, Ni/CeO2-500 was selected as the optimal catalyst for subsequent hydrogenolysis. Then a series of solvent screening experiments for BPE hydrogenolysis were carried out in isopropanol, ethanol, methanol and n-hexane at 120 °C under 1.5 MPa H2. The resulting BPE conversions were 100%, 85.0%, 70.5%, and 87.2%, respectively (Table S3). However, BPE showed no reaction in isopropanol under 1.5 MPa N₂. These results indicate that the hydrogen for BPE hydrogenolysis comes primarily from external H2, not the solvent. Therefore, the superiority of isopropanol is attributed to its good solubility toward the substrate rather than its hydrogen-donating capacity. Therefore, isopropanol and external H2 were adopted as the standard conditions in all subsequent experiments. Fig. 6 illustrates the effects of reaction conditions on BPE conversion and product distribution during hydrogenolysis. As shown in Fig. 6a, increasing the reaction temperature from 80 °C to 100 °C dramatically improved BPE conversion from negligible levels to 100%, accompanied by exclusive cleavage of the benzylic C-O bond to yield only toluene and phenol. Further elevation beyond 100 °C maintained complete conversion but reduced phenol selectivity, as indicated by the formation of minor cyclohexanol. Hydrogenolysis of C-O bonds and hydrogenation of aromatic rings are two mutually competitive pathways during BPE hydroconversion. Lower temperatures favor hydrogenolysis while elevated temperatures favor arene hydrogenation. The electron-donating hydroxyl substituent of phenol increases the susceptibility of its aromatic ring to hydrogenation relative to toluene, as evidenced by cyclohexanol formation above 100 °C. Evidently, higher temperature could also facilitate the hydrogenation of toluene to methylcyclohexane. Based on the dual criteria of complete BPE conversion (100%) and maximum aromatic monomer selectivity, 100 °C was identified as the optimal temperature for selective C-O bond cleavage in BPE. Fig. 6b shows the dependence of BPE hydrogenolysis on H2 pressure. Conversion increased from 71.3% to 100% as initial H2 pressure rose from 0.5 MPa to 1.5 MPa, plateauing between 1.5-2.5 MPa. Surprisingly, cyclohexanol, indicative of arene hydrogenation, was detected only at lower pressures (0.5-1.0 MPa), disappearing completely above 1.5 MPa. This inverse pressure dependence suggests that for BPE elevated H2 pressure may suppress arene hydrogenation. Therefore, 1.5 MPa was selected as the optimal initial H2 pressure, ensuring complete BPE conversion while maintaining exclusive hydrogenolysis selectivity. Fig. 6c depicts the temporal evolution of BPE hydrogenolysis over Ni/CeO2-500 at 100 °C and 1.5 MPa H2. BPE conversion reached 39.11% within 1.5 h and achieved completion (100%) at 2h. Extending the reaction time to 2.5 h maintained complete conversion with no detectable side products, as confirmed by sustained >99% selectivity to toluene/phenol and absence of hydrogenated species (e.g., cyclohexanol). Therefore, 2 h was identified as the optimal reaction time, balancing complete BPE conversion with uncompromised hydrogenolysis selectivity. Finally, the effects of catalyst loading on BPE hydrogenolysis were investigated under optimized conditions (100 °C, 1.5 MPa H2, 2 h). Fig. 6d reveals a pronounced loading-activity dependence: BPE conversion increased from negligible levels to 84.7% as the Ni/CeO2-500 dosage rose from 5 mg to 15 mg, reaching full conversion (100%) at 25 mg. Moreover, even at higher loadings (35 mg), no hydrogenated byproducts (e.g. cyclohexanol or methylcyclohexane) were detected, confirming the exceptional selectivity of Ni/CeO2-500 for C-O bond cleavage over competitive arene hydrogenation. 3.3 Catalytic hydrogenolysis of β-O-4 lignin model compound The hydrogenolysis of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol (2-PPE), a β-O-4 lignin model compound, was systematically investigated over Ni/CeO2-T catalysts. At 120 °C (Fig. 7a ), only 5.8% conversion was observed with phenol and 1-phenylethanol as primary products (43.6% each), and phenethyl phenyl ether as a minor product (12.9%). Remarkably, increasing the temperature to 180 °C achieved complete conversion and triggered product redistribution: ethylbenzene (47.8%) and cyclohexanol (34.2%) dominated, while phenol and 1-phenylethanol decreased to 15.8% and 2.2%, respectively. At 200 °C, quantitative conversion yielded exclusive ethylbenzene and cyclohexanol in equimolar ratio (50% each), indicating that elevated temperatures concurrently promote C-O bond cleavage, arene hydrogenation and side-chain hydrodeoxygenation. Balancing aromatic monomer yield against conversion efficiency, 180 °C was selected for subsequent experiments of 2-PPE. Fig. 7b depicts the effects of initial H2 pressure on 2-PPE hydrogenolysis at 180 °C (0.5-2.5 MPa). Complete conversion occurred across all pressures, yet product distribution shifted significantly. Increasing H2 pressure from 0.5 to 2.0 MPa decreased phenol selectivity from 22.5% to 15.5% and 1-phenylethanol selectivity from 10.7% to 4.5%, while cyclohexanol selectivity increased slightly from 27.5% to 30.0%. This trend indicates enhanced arene hydrogenation and hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) at elevated H2 pressure. Consequently, 0.5 MPa H2 pressure maximized aromatic monomer yield by favoring C-O bond cleavage over ring saturation, thus establishing it as the optimal pressure for selective hydrogenolysis of 2-PPE. As shown in Fig. 7c, complete 2-PPE conversion (100%) persisted across 0.5-2.5 h at 180 °C and 0.5 MPa H₂, while product distribution evolved with reaction time. Phenol selectivity decreased sharply from 37.1% to 13.8% and 1-phenylethanol from 29.7% to 3.8%, whereas cyclohexanol selectivity increased from 18.8% to 46.2% and ethylbenzene rose from 11.4% to 36.3%. Product redistribution reflects progressive arene hydrogenation (e.g., phenol to cyclohexanol) and side-chain hydrodeoxygenation (e.g., 1-phenylethanol to ethylbenzene), revealing kinetic competition between initial C-O cleavage and consecutive arene hydrogenation/HDO pathways. 3.4 DFT calculations for lignin model compounds conversion over Ni/CeO2-500 To elucidate the reaction mechanism, we performed radical trapping experiments by introducing TEMPO (2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidin-1-oxyl) into the reaction system. As shown in Fig. S5, complete BPE conversion to toluene and phenol was achieved in the absence of TEMPO, whereas minimal conversion occurred in the presence of TEMPO. This significant suppression effect indicates that C-O bond cleavage of BPE and related lignin models over Ni/CeO₂-500 proceeds via radical-mediated pathway. To further unravel the pathways of C-O bond cleavage, systematic density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed on BPE and 2-PPE conversion over Ni/CeO2-500. Computational models revealed that oxygen vacancies (Ov) in CeO2, primarily generated during high-temperature calcination, serve as nucleation sites for Ni clusters. DFT-optimized structures revealed that tetrahedral Ni4 clusters preferentially anchored on CeO2 (111) surfaces (Fig. 8a ), forming interfacial Ni-Ov-Ce sites. Ni incorporation induces partial reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+, creating additional Ov sites to maintain charge balance. The incorporated Ni2+ ions then replace Ce4+/Ce3+ in the lattice, driving charge-compensating isovalent doping that generates multi-phase interfaces and further concentrates Ov sites near Ni clusters. Therefore, aromatic rings in BPE and 2-PPE adsorb onto nickel clusters, while ether oxygen atoms coordinate with adjacent oxygen vacancies at Ni-CeO₂ interfaces. This synergistic dual-active-center mechanism facilitates substrate adsorption, as confirmed by DFT calculations showing adsorption energies of -1.26 eV for BPE and -2.23 eV for 2-PPE on Ni/CeO2-500 (Fig. 8), 0.7-1.2 eV enhancements versus adsorption on oxygen-deficient CeO₂. H2 undergoes dissociative adsorption on highly dispersed nickel clusters, forming activated hydrogen species (H⋯H) that evolve into hydrogen radicals (H•). These electrophilic H• radicals are stabilized by electronic interactions with oxygen-containing groups in the substrates, thus facilitating C-O bond cleavage [46]. As depicted in Fig. 9 , DFT calculations revealed that the homolytic cleavage of C-O bond in BPE to generate benzyl and phenoxy radicals has an activation barrier of +1.2 eV, much lower than the α-O-4 bond dissociation energy (BDE: 2.24-2.50 eV), demonstrating that Ni-Ov dual sites not only enhance substrate adsorption but also weaken C-O bonds. The reduced dissociation energy barrier enables hydrogenolysis to proceed under mild conditions (100 °C). The resultant benzyl and phenoxy radicals subsequently undergo rapid hydrogenation with H• to form toluene (3) and phenol (4). Further hydrogenation of phenol (4) to cyclohexanol (5) has a higher activation barrier of +1.83 eV, which aligns with the experimentally observed temperature-dependent increase in cyclohexanol formation. DFT-calculated energy profiles (Fig. 10 ) and mechanistic pathways (Fig. 11 ) reveal three competing routes for 2-PPE conversion over Ni/CeO₂-500. Direct C-O bond cleavage (red pathway) has the lowest activation energy of +1.68 eV, forming 1-phenylethanol and phenoxy radicals. This barrier is 1.08 eV lower than that of dehydration/hydrogenation pathway (E a = +2.76 eV) and 0.35 eV lower than that of dehydroxylation pathway (E a = +2.03 eV, blue pathway), establishing direct cleavage as the kinetically dominant pathway. The resulting radicals undergo rapid hydrogenation to form 1-phenylethanol (6) and phenol (8). Subsequent dehydration and hydrogenation of 1-phenylethanol to ethylbenzene (7) are kinetically favored relative to phenol hydrogenation to cyclohexanol (9), with activation energies of +0.11 eV and +0.82 eV, respectively. This energy difference is consistent with experimental observation of ethylbenzene/cyclohexanol selectivity (1.4:1 at 180°C). The alternative pathway for 1-phenylethanol formation, involving benzylic hydrogen abstraction, C-O bond cleavage, and double-bond hydrogenation (E a = +2.76 eV, green pathway), exhibits a significantly higher energy barrier than direct cleavage (+1.68 eV). The energy difference explains the negligible contribution of blue pathway, as confirmed by the absence of acetophenone in GC-MS analysis. Consistent with this trend, the minor pathway involving benzyl hydrogen abstraction in PPE (phenethyl phenyl ether) exhibits a significantly higher activation energy (E a = +2.40 eV, orange pathway in Fig. 10) than direct C-O bond hydrocracking (E a = +1.47 eV, blue pathway). This 0.93 eV energy difference rationalizes the dominance of C-O cleavage pathway, which generates phenethyl and phenoxy radicals as key intermediates for subsequent ethylbenzene and cyclohexanol formation. Consequently, DFT calculations establish that C-O bond dissociation is energetically favored over arene hydrogenation in both major and minor reaction pathways over Ni/CeO2-500. 3.5 Catalytic hydrogenolysis of other lignin model compounds Given the structural diversity of C-O bonds in lignin (e.g., α-O-4, β-O-4, 4-O-5), we evaluated the hydrogenolysis of other lignin model compounds over Ni/CeO2-500 under optimized condition (180 °C, 0.5 MPa H2, 0.5 h). As listed in Table 4 , the β-O-4 model compound, 2-(2-methoxyphenoxy)-1-(4-methoxyphenyl) ethenone (entry 1), underwent selective cleavage with 100% aromatic monomer selectivity. Notably, under reduced temperature (140 °C) and elevated H2 pressure (1.5 MPa, entry 2), the substrate was completely converted to 1-methoxy-4-vinylbenzene and guaiacol in a 1:1 molar ratio, with no detectable arene hydrogenation byproducts. These findings further confirm the catalyst's exclusive selectivity toward C-O bond scission. Even for substrates with electron-rich aromatic moieties which are prone to arene hydrogenation, hydrogenolysis remains the exclusive pathway. Diphenyl ether (4-O-5 model) achieved 81.2% aromatic monomer selectivity at 71% conversion, yielding benzene, phenol and cyclohexanol. In contrast, the α-O-4 model compound dibenzyl ether exclusively produced toluene via sequential C-O cleavage to toluene and benzyl alcohol followed by efficient hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of benzyl alcohol. Control experiment with benzyl alcohol under identical conditions revealed 93.5% HDO pathway to toluene, versus 6.5% arene hydrogenation to cyclohexyl methanol. This preferential HDO pathway is attributed to Ni-Ov-mediated dual adsorption, which elongates C-OH bonds and lowers the HDO activation barrier. For benzyl-2-naphthyl ether, complete conversion was achieved, yielding toluene and naphthalene-derived products through efficient C-O cleavage. Nevertheless, Ni/CeO2-500 with abundant oxygen vacancies efficiently cleaved diverse C-O bonds spanning α-O-4, β-O-4 and 4-O-5 motifs, highlighting the significant potential for natural lignin valorization. 4 Conclusions In summary, Ni/CeO₂-500 catalyst enables highly selective hydrogenolysis of C–O bonds in lignin-derived aryl ethers under mild conditions (100-180 °C), achieving near-quantitative conversion of model compounds (e.g., BPE converted to toluene and phenol) while preserving aromatic rings. Synergistic effects of Ni nanoparticles and neighboring oxygen vacancies were unequivocally established through combined experimental and DFT studies. Ni active sites mediate H₂ adsorption/dissociation into H• radicals while facilitating substrate adsorption through Ni-arene interaction. Oxygen vacancies enhance substrate adsorption via the coordination of Ov to oxygen containing groups, elongate C-O bonds, and facilitate H•-companied C-O bond cleavage. This work establishes a robust strategy for lignin valorization, bridging the gap between model reactions and real lignin depolymerization. coredata.dc:description: Developing simple and efficient catalytic systems for cleaving bridged linkages in lignin has emerged as a promising valorization strategy. In this work, a series of Ni/CeO2 catalysts calcined at 400-800 °C were prepared and evaluated for the selective hydrogenolysis of lignin-derived aryl ethers. Among them, Ni/CeO2-500 demonstrated optimal activity, achieving complete conversion of benzyl phenyl ether (BPE) at 100 °C with 100% selectivity to toluene and phenol (no detectable arene hydrogenation byproducts). For the more robust β-O-4 and 4-O-5 model compounds, 71%-100% conversion with 81.22%-100% selectivity to aromatic monomers were attained at 180°C. Catalyst characterization revealed that calcination at 500 °C optimized oxygen vacancy (Ov) concentration as evidenced by XPS analysis of OIII/OI+OII ratio and Ce³⁺/Ce⁴⁺ ratio. Furthermore, density functional theory (DFT) calculations elucidated a dual-site mechanism: Ni sites facilitate H₂ dissociation and interaction with aromatic rings, and adjacent Ov sites activate C-O bonds via coordination to oxygen-containing functional groups. The synergistic Ni-Ov cooperation enhances substrate adsorption and lowers the C-O bond dissociation energy by 1.04-1.32 eV, thereby promoting selective hydrogenolysis over arene hydrogenation at lower temperatures. The Ni/CeO₂-500 system demonstrates significant potential for efficient lignin depolymerization under mild conditions, offering new insights for designing non-noble metal catalysts in biomass valorization.
